title: How Teachers Are Using Soroban in American Classrooms
description: Real examples of soroban integration from K-5 classrooms across the US.
imageAlt: Teacher using soroban with students in classroom

content.intro: Soroban isn't just for after-school enrichment. More American teachers are integrating it into regular math instruction. Here's how they're doing it.

items: Addresses Common Core number sense standards
Provides concrete representation for abstract concepts
Challenges advanced students with mental math

sections.text: "We start every morning with 5 minutes of soroban practice. Students log into the app, do a quick practice, and we move on. It's not a big thing – just a warm-up. But over the year, the mental math improvement is visible."
"Soroban is one of 4 rotation stations during math block. While I teach small groups, others rotate through independent practice, games, and soroban. 15 minutes, 3 times a week."
"We offer soroban as an enrichment option for students who finish classwork early or want extra challenge. It's not mandatory, but about half my class is doing it voluntarily."
Teacher: Mrs. Rivera, Math Interventionist, Florida
"I use soroban specifically with students who struggle with place value and number sense. The visual representation helps concepts click that weren't clicking with abstract numbers."
Notice: No one replaced their math curriculum with soroban. It supplements, not substitutes.

rows: Column structure visualizes place value directly

sections.text: You don't need soroban certification. Learn basics yourself (takes ~2-4 hours), then use the app to guide students. The technology does the heavy lifting.
Explain to parents: "We're using an additional tool to build mental math skills. It's the same abacus used in Japan where students consistently score highest in international math rankings."

faq.question: Will parents complain that it's not "real math"?
faq.answer: Some might. Have research ready. Also, when their kids start doing mental math faster than they can, complaints usually stop.

faq.question: How do I justify the time?
faq.answer: 5-15 minutes/day is minimal. The return in mental math fluency and number sense pays for itself in easier instruction later.

faq.question: What grade should start soroban?
faq.answer: 1st-2nd is ideal. Kindergarten can start very basic. 3rd-5th can still benefit but need to catch up to younger starters.
